concepts.title: Story Summary ‚Äî Prejudice and Acceptance
concepts.content: Rima mocks Malti ‚Äî a new girl from another state ‚Äî for her appearance (oily hair, long skirt) and poor English accent. Rima's clique (small exclusive group) bullies Malti. But Malti wins the singing competition and excels at maths. When Malti asks Rima for help with English, Rima refuses cruelly. Even Rima's friends turn against her, showing she has gone too far.

examples.text: Malti sings beautifully ‚Äî even the Principal applauds first
Malti's forte: maths ‚Äî classmates seek her help
Malti asks Rima for English help ‚Äî Rima refuses rudely
Rima's own friends say 'That was horrid, Rima'

keyPoints: Prejudice: judging others without knowing them
Forte: a person's area of greatest strength
Clique: small exclusive group that excludes others
Judging by appearance or accent is wrong
True worth is shown through actions, not looks
concepts.funFact: üåç India has 22 official languages ‚Äî every Indian is 'Malti' in some language other than their own!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 3-6: Odd One In by Tithi Tavora

concepts.title: Character Analysis ‚Äî Malti and Rima
concepts.content: Malti: quiet, studious, intelligent, gifted singer, maths genius, generous (helps classmates), dignified under bullying. Rima: stylish, good at English singing, but proud and unkind ‚Äî a snob. Her parents are worried: 'We put Rima into a good school to make her smart and confident. I am afraid she is turning into quite a little snob!'

examples.text: Malti: bright, studious, fares well in sports and studies
Malti: 'Her simple appearance belied a sharp and nimble brain'
Rima: snob, clique-leader, stubborn dislike of Malti
Mr Sen: 'The same may be said of your Hindi' ‚Äî sharp reply to Rima

keyPoints: Malti: belied = appearance hid her true intelligence
Rima: atrocious = very poor quality (she said Malti's English)
Snob: person who looks down on those considered inferior
Rima came first in singing but felt 'no joy'
Inner conflict: Rima knew she was wrong but was too proud to admit it
concepts.funFact: üé≠ The story's title 'Odd One In' (not 'Odd One Out') is intentional ‚Äî Malti is different but she BELONGS in the group!

concepts.title: Message of the Story
concepts.content: The story teaches us never to judge people by their appearance, accent, clothing or state of origin. Intelligence, talent and character are what truly matter. Speaking good English is not the only mark of intelligence. Being kind and helping others shows real character. The story ends before Rima apologises ‚Äî we are left to imagine what happens next.

examples.text: Malti's talent proved itself ‚Äî singing prize, maths genius
Lesson: judge by character, not by appearance or accent
Workshop: write about your own strengths and weaknesses
Words ending in '-ly' from passage: roundly, uncharitably, stubbornly

keyPoints: Never judge by appearance, accent, dress or origin
Talent and character are more important than language skills
Language learning takes time ‚Äî be patient and kind
List adverbs ending in '-ly': roundly, snidely, stubbornly
Workshop: compare Malti and Rima ‚Äî appearance, studies, singing, attitude
concepts.funFact: üåê English has only been India's language for ~200 years. Sanskrit, Tamil and other Indian languages are thousands of years older!
concepts.textbookRef: Page 7: English Workshop and Language Study

concepts.title: Common Nouns vs Proper Nouns
concepts.content: Common nouns are general names for people, places or things (girl, city, river, table). Proper nouns are the specific names of particular persons, places or organisations ‚Äî always written with a capital letter (Rima, Mumbai, Ahmednagar, Seva Hospital, The Times of India).

examples.text: Common: girl, boy, town, river, table, pencil
Proper: Sangeeta, Rahul, London, Nashik, Sahyadri
Multi-word proper nouns: Seva Hospital, The Times of India
Rule: Proper nouns always start with a capital letter

keyPoints: Common noun: general name (not specific): girl, city, river
Proper noun: specific name (always capitalised): Mumbai, Rima
Multi-word proper nouns also capitalised: Indian Ocean, New Delhi
Proper nouns can be people, places, organisations, brands
Test: Would you use 'the' before it? Common nouns usually yes; proper nouns no
concepts.funFact: üìå Your own name is a proper noun ‚Äî that's why it's always written with a capital letter, in every language!
concepts.textbookRef: Page 7: Language Study ‚Äî Common and Proper Nouns

concepts.title: Vocabulary from the Story
concepts.content: Key vocabulary from 'Odd One In': sniffed = said in a scornful way; insufferable = unbearable; atrocious = extremely poor; forte = greatest strength; clique = small exclusive group; belied = contradicted/hid; recounted = told again; snidely = in a nasty manner; jeer = make rude remarks; roundly = in an emphatic manner.

examples.text: Smart: intelligent (general) vs smart = stylish (context-specific)
Forte: 'Her forte was mathematics' = her greatest strength
Snob: a person who looks down on others
Belied: 'Her simple appearance belied a sharp brain' = hid/contradicted

keyPoints: forte (n): one's strong point or talent
clique (n): small exclusive social group
atrocious (adj): extremely bad
belied (v): gave a false impression of
Adverbs ending '-ly': snidely, roundly, stubbornly, uncharitably
concepts.funFact: üåê The word 'snob' may come from Latin 'sine nobilitate' meaning 'without nobility' ‚Äî ironically, real nobles were rarely snobbish!

test.question: Why did Rima and her gang chorus 'Gud marning!' to Malti?
test.explanation: Rima and her gang were making fun of Malti's accent and pronunciation of 'Good morning'.

test.question: What happened at the Inter-House singing competition?
options: Malti won first prize with her beautiful singing
Rima won the Hindi singing prize
test.explanation: Malti sang beautifully and won first prize. Even Rima's gang was silenced by the performance.

test.question: Why did Rima feel no joy after winning her singing category?
options: She knew she had been cruel to Malti
She wanted to win the Hindi category too
test.explanation: Rima won first in her English song category but she knew she had been unkind to Malti, so she felt no real happiness.

test.question: Which is a proper noun?
test.explanation: Ahmednagar is the specific name of a place ‚Äî it is a proper noun and always written with a capital letter.

test.question: What did Mr Sen mean by 'The same may be said of your Hindi'?
options: Rima's Hindi is also not perfect, so she should not mock others' English
Hindi is more important than English
test.explanation: Mr Sen was pointing out that Rima mocks Malti's English but her own Hindi is probably also imperfect ‚Äî we should not judge others for language weaknesses we may also have.

test.question: What is a 'clique'?
options: A small group of friends who do not allow others to join them
test.explanation: A clique is a small group of friends who do not allow others to join them. Rima and her gang formed a clique that excluded Malti.

test.question: 'Her simple appearance belied a sharp and nimble brain' means _____.
options: Her appearance hid how intelligent she really was
She looked smart and was also smart
test.explanation: Belied means 'gave a false impression of'. Malti looked simple but she had a sharp brain ‚Äî her appearance hid her intelligence.

test.question: Which of these is a common noun?
test.explanation: River is a common noun ‚Äî a general name for a type of water body. Nashik, Rima and India are proper nouns.

test.question: Malti asked Rima for help with _____.
test.explanation: Malti said: 'I know my English is weak. Yours is good. Please, will you help me to improve it?' ‚Äî she asked Rima for help with English.

test.question: What did Rima's parents mean by 'she is turning into quite a little snob'?
options: Rima was looking down on others and judging them unfairly
Rima was spending too much money
test.explanation: A snob looks down on people they consider inferior. Rima judged Malti by her appearance, accent and origin ‚Äî exactly what a snob does.

keyConcepts: Story: Rima bullies Malti for appearance/accent; Malti proves her worth through talent
Forte: greatest strength; Clique: exclusive group; Belied: hid true nature
Message: judge by character, not appearance or language skills
Common nouns: general names (girl, city); Proper nouns: specific names (Mumbai, Rima)
Proper nouns always start with a capital letter
Multi-word proper nouns: The Times of India, Seva Hospital
commonMisconceptions: Proper nouns are only people's names ‚Äî FALSE, places, brands, organisations too
Rima was a bad student ‚Äî FALSE, she won her singing category
Malti was weak ‚Äî FALSE, her forte was mathematics; she was studious and talented
realWorldExamples: New student from another state ‚Äî happens in every school in India
Mumbai is a proper noun; 'city' is a common noun
India has 22 official languages ‚Äî being fluent in English doesn't define intelligence
